t: Job 33
“But*pn now, Job, listen to my words; pay*ld attention to everything I say.
I*ln am about to open my mouth; my*ld words are on the tip of my tongue.
My*ln words come from an upright heart; my*ld lips sincerely speak what I know.
The*ln Spirit of God has made me; the*ld breath of the Almighty gives me life.
Answer*ln me then, if you can; stand*ld up and argue your case before me.
I*ln am the same as you in God’s sight; I*ld too am a piece of clay.
No*ln fear of me should alarm you, nor*ld should my hand be heavy on you.
“But*pn you have said in my hearing— I*ld heard the very words—
‘I*ln am pure, I have done no wrong; I*ld am clean and free from sin.
Yet*ln God has found fault with me; he*ld considers me his enemy.
He*ln fastens my feet in shackles; he*ld keeps close watch on all my paths.’
“But*pn I tell you, in this you are not right, for*ld God is greater than any mortal.
Why*ln do you complain to him that*ld he responds to no one’s words?
For*ln God does speak—now one way, now another— though*ld no one perceives it.
In*ln a dream, in a vision of the night, when*ld deep sleep falls on people as*ld they slumber in their beds,
he*ln may speak in their ears and*ld terrify them with warnings,
to*ln turn them from wrongdoing and*ld keep them from pride,
to*ln preserve them from the pit, their*ld lives from perishing by the sword.
“Or*pn someone may be chastened on a bed of pain with*ld constant distress in their bones,
so*ln that their body finds food repulsive and*ld their soul loathes the choicest meal.
Their*ln flesh wastes away to nothing, and*ld their bones, once hidden, now stick out.
They*ln draw near to the pit, and*ld their life to the messengers of death.
Yet*ln if there is an angel at their side, a*ld messenger, one out of a thousand, sent*ld to tell them how to be upright,
and*ln he is gracious to that person and says to God, ‘Spare*ld them from going down to the pit; I*ld have found a ransom for them—
let*ln their flesh be renewed like a child’s; let*ld them be restored as in the days of their youth’—
then*ln that person can pray to God and find favor with him, they*ld will see God’s face and shout for joy; he*ld will restore them to full well-being.
And*ln they will go to others and say, ‘I*ld have sinned, I have perverted what is right, but*ld I did not get what I deserved.
God*ln has delivered me from going down to the pit, and*ld I shall live to enjoy the light of life.’
“God*pn does all these things to a person— twice,*ld even three times—
to*ln turn them back from the pit, that*ld the light of life may shine on them.
“Pay*pn attention, Job, and listen to me; be*ld silent, and I will speak.
If*ln you have anything to say, answer me; speak*ld up, for I want to vindicate you.
But*ln if not, then listen to me; be*ld silent, and I will teach you wisdom.”
